description: Interface up notification
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD IF-TRAP::interfaceUp TRAPS-COMMON::alarmType s EXAMPLE TRAPS-COMMON::alarmDevice s EXAMPLE TRAPS-COMMON::alarmObject s EXAMPLE TRAPS-COMMON::alarmSpecificProblem s EXAMPLE TRAPS-COMMON::alarmClass i 0 TRAPS-COMMON::alarmEventType i 1 TRAPS-COMMON::alarmProbableCause i 1 TRAPS-COMMON::alarmTime s EXAMPLEE TRAPS-COMMON::alarmSeverity i 1 TRAPS-COMMON::alarmHasClear i 1 TRAPS-COMMON::alarmText s EXAMPLE TRAPS-COMMON::tenantName s EXAMPLE IF-TRAP::ifOperStatus i 1 IF-TRAP::ifIndex i 9999 IF-TRAP::ifAdminStatus i 1 IF-TRAP::ifOrderId s EXAMPLE

description: This provides an identification of the alarm type. Together
with tfAlarmSpecificProblem, this is a unique identification
of the alarm. Different managed object types and instances
can share alarm types, but if the same managed object reports
the same alarm type, it is to be considered as the same alarm
state. The alarm type is a simplification of the different
X.733 and 3GPP alarm IRP alarm correlation mechanisms based
on EventType, ProbableCause, SpecificProblem and
NotificationId.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmType

description: The name of the managed device. May also be the system
itself for self-management alarms. Note that this object is
not fine-grained enough to pinpoint the alarming
resource. The alarm object within the device is the exact
alarming resource.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmDevice

description: Name of alarm object within a device based on YANG
naming. Note that the granularity must be good enough to
guarantee unique alarm states and relevant resource
identification to the operator.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmObject

description: This object is used when the 'tfAlarmType' object cannot
uniquely identify the alarm type. Normally, this is not the
case, and this leaf is the empty string.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmSpecificProblem

description: The severity of the alarm as defined by X.733. Note that
this may not be the original severity since the alarm may
have changed severity. For cleared alarms, this is the last
severity that is not equal to cleared.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmClass

description: The event type as defined in X.733/X.736.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmEventType

description: The probable cause as defined in X.733/X.736.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmProbableCause

description: A time stamp of the alarm state change event. Note that this
variable represents the last change of the alarm state, like
changed severity or additional text. If the alarm has not
changed state this variable represents the alarm raise time
and will be the same as tfAlarmOrigTime.
NOTE: All fields of the DateAndTime MUST be filled out
including the hours and minutes from UTC. As such, the value
should be 11 octets long.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmTime

description: The severity of the alarm as defined by X.733. Note that
this may not be the original severity since the alarm may
have changed severity. For cleared alarms, this is the last
severity that is not equal to cleared.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmSeverity

description: Indicates if the alarm is cleared or not.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmHasClear

description: A user friendly text describing the alarm.
Intended for human consumption.
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::alarmText

description: Tenant name
variables.name: TRAPS-COMMON::tenantName

description: The current operational state of the interface. The
testing(3) state indicates that no operational packets can
be passed. If ifAdminStatus is down(2) then ifOperStatus
should be down(2). If ifAdminStatus is changed to up(1)
then ifOperStatus should change to up(1) if the interface is
ready to transmit and receive network traffic; it should
change to dormant(5) if the interface is waiting for
external actions (such as a serial line waiting for an
incoming connection); it should remain in the down(2) state
if and only if there is a fault that prevents it from going
to the up(1) state; it should remain in the notPresent(6)
state if the interface has missing (typically, hardware)
components
variables.name: IF-TRAP::ifOperStatus

description: A unique value, greater than zero, for each interface.
It is recommended that values are assigned contiguously
starting from 1. The value for each interface sub-layer
must remain constant at least from one re-initialization of
the entity's network management system to the next re-
initialization
variables.name: IF-TRAP::ifIndex

description: The desired state of the interface. The testing(3) state
indicates that no operational packets can be passed. When a
managed system initializes, all interfaces start with
ifAdminStatus in the down(2) state. As a result of either
explicit management action or per configuration information
retained by the managed system, ifAdminStatus is then
changed to either the up(1) or testing(3) states (or remains
in the down(2) state)
variables.name: IF-TRAP::ifAdminStatus

description: A string describing order id
variables.name: IF-TRAP::ifOrderId

description: Interface down notification
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD IF-TRAP::interfaceDown TRAPS-COMMON::alarmType s EXAMPLE TRAPS-COMMON::alarmDevice s EXAMPLE TRAPS-COMMON::alarmObject s EXAMPLE TRAPS-COMMON::alarmSpecificProblem s EXAMPLE TRAPS-COMMON::alarmClass i 0 TRAPS-COMMON::alarmEventType i 1 TRAPS-COMMON::alarmProbableCause i 1 TRAPS-COMMON::alarmTime s EXAMPLEE TRAPS-COMMON::alarmSeverity i 1 TRAPS-COMMON::alarmHasClear i 1 TRAPS-COMMON::alarmText s EXAMPLE TRAPS-COMMON::tenantName s EXAMPLE IF-TRAP::ifOperStatus i 1 IF-TRAP::ifIndex i 9999 IF-TRAP::ifAdminStatus i 1 IF-TRAP::ifOrderId s EXAMPLE
